document:
Media playback is unsupported on your device
31 March 2014 Last updated at 12:30 BST
It will be able to issue warning and banning orders against agents acting dishonestly or breaching estate agent laws.
The move follows a decision by the UK government to disband the OFT.
Powys won the competitive bidding process to deliver the service in place of the OFT and will receive Â£170,000 a year to carry out the work.
People complaining about estate agents will still contact their local authority trading standards department, who will prosecute offenders if necessary.
However they will refer cases to Powys if they believe parts of the Estate Agents Act have been breached.
James Munro from Powys council, who will lead the new team, has said he hopes it will show Powys could take on more contracts and outside work in future.
He spoke to Radio Wales' Good Morning Wales' Peter Johnson about what the new role will involve.
claim: estate agents in powys have said they are considering banning agents operating on their estate.

sum_sents: estate agents in powys have said they are considering banning agents operating on their estate.
cot:
1. The summary statements are all supported by the article.
Therefore, the answer is yes, the summary is consistent with the article.
human_reason:
1. The summary suggests that estate agents in Powys are considering banning agents operating on their estate, which is not mentioned in the article. Instead, the article states that Powys Council will be responsible for enforcing the Estate Agents Act and issuing warning and banning orders to agents who breach the law.
Therefore, the answer is no, the summary is not consistent with the article.
gpt-3.5-turbo-0301:
1. The article discusses the creation of a new team in Powys to regulate estate agents.
2. The team will be able to issue warning and banning orders against agents acting dishonestly or breaching estate agent laws.
3. The UK government disbanded the OFT, leading to the creation of this new team.
4. Powys won the competitive bidding process to deliver the service and will receive £170,000 a year to carry out the work.
5. People complaining about estate agents will still contact their local authority trading standards department, who will prosecute offenders if necessary.
6. However, cases may be referred to Powys if parts of the Estate Agents Act have been breached.
7. James Munro from Powys council will lead the new team.
8. He hopes that the new role will show Powys could take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

The summary is not consistent with the article. The article does not mention estate agents in Powys considering banning agents operating on their estate.
